ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Super cool lab class that really covers many physiological topics through interesting labs: breaking chicken bones, taking an ECG, stimulating your thumb to twitch, and measuring your respiratory capacity.
MATLAB, collecting basic biosignals, analyzing data
I learned how to take, process, and interpret biosignals relevant to todays medical landscape.
Learned how to use cool software/hardware; learned about the physiology of our bones, heart and lungs.

I learned how to work with MATLAB at a basic level to gather and interpret lab data. I also learned about several physiological concepts including respiration, neuromuscular signaling, and bone structure.
Bit of practical experience using various tools related to physiological like measuring bone strength, ECG, and MATLAB signal processing basics.

I learned a variety of different physiological lab techniques as well as the basis for measuring biosignals such as EMG, EKG, etc. Also, I became more proficient in using MATLAB to clean, analyze, and plot data.
Learned how to use various machines in lab which was cool.
This class is a really good class to show types of experiments we would be handling as biomedical engineers. You really get to focus on data analysis, and learn alot of new things.
Lab report writing, collaborative efforts, and many different biomedical topics.

This course provided an introduction to the various systems we learned in physiology, such as bone biomechanics, biosignal processing, and ECG. We learned about how to take measurements of the body and use MATLAB to process data.
I learned how to analyze biomedical data using Matlab regarding some concepts covered in the physiological systems course

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
-The in person labs really reinforce learning and understanding of topics previously taught in human physiology

-I am just sad the respiratory lab was not in person (COVID)

Strengths: interesting labs, every other week schedule was nice
Weaknesses: I never really got to know my professors at all

The every other week format is great and I think that the large amount of time spent on the lab reports definitely makes up for the less than usual class time. The class was well structured and the reports were self explanatory, but they did take a very long time to do.

Strengths: short in lab components, doesn't take too much time
Weaknesses: None really. this is required for many majors and compared to previous lab experiences at yale, this one was definitely the best! Note, you need to know matlab!
Too many teachers and too little guidance! The lab reports were not very specific on what they wanted and it ended up making them take ages longer than they should have.
I enjoyed the format of the course in which is met every other week and how the lab was very hands on.

I thought this course was effective at providing interesting, engaging, fun labs. I particularly enjoyed the labs on cardiac function, bones, and neuromuscular signaling. It was also very helpful that we worked in the same groups every week, eliminating the traditional awkward dynamics that come with weekly new groups. I also appreciated that we often finished labs early and came in every other week, instead of every week. The lab reports were time-intensive and MATLAB could be frustrating, but it was nice to be able devote full engagement to the lab on "on" weeks and then take a week off to regather my lab energy. I wish the lab matched up better with the lecture course, and it often felt like a physics lab when I would have loved to focus more on non-physics physiology material (although I understand signaling aligns very well with physics for data collection). The TAs were also great for help with lab reports.
Lab reports could be more guided

Strengths: not too too much work (good since half credit), interesting and fun lab assignments. Lab reports weren't terrible (didn't take too much time usually or ask overly specific questions)
Weaknesses: I am in general not a huge fan of lab courses. Although you get some hands on experience, it doesn't really mimic really research. The lab reports aren't very useful in my view. So this course suffers many of the same issues of other lab courses.

Strengths: lab reports are not excessively time-consuming or difficult, labs were fairly short compared to introductory STEM lab courses, the pre-lab lectures were helpful, final exam was fair

Weaknesses: sometimes questions on the lab reports were a little bit unclear but I was able to clarify them at TF office hours

The strengths of this course is that it is not an overbearing lab like other yale labs yet it was still challenging. I thought the feedback from the lab reports weren't the best and lost some points due to inconsistent grading. Weakness is that the final exam was a bit difficult and there was no real way of knowing what type of questions we were going to be given.
I really liked how lab was every other week. This setup made the class alot more fun, and helped with the workload of other classes, allowing me to be more engaged.
i wish there was more structure. Although the pre-lab material was clear and the procedures were helpful, I wish we had a clear picture of the end goal and purpose of the lab beforehand

I thought the labs were fair and pretty straightforward. The professors were all extremely kind and willing to help during the lab to make sure we understood what we were doing. Sometimes the lab reports were a tad long and confusing in wording. The turnaround between turning in our lab report and getting our grades back sometimes took a while, so it was hard to figure out how to improve later labs as to not make the same mistakes.
The introductions to the labs seemed like a wall of specific information at first, so be prepared for extensive preparation before each lab (mostly regarding extra readings)
The schedule is really nice with the alternating weeks of in lab and reports due, because you can focus on the reports much better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's a great pre-med lab.
It's a chill lab, some of the lab reports are quite a lot of work, however and will require you e-mail the TF's or go to Office Hours. But as far as labs go, there are worst ones.
Yes, but only if you're BME. I felt like I didn't learn that much as there were only 5 labs, but this could also be because of COVID protocol.

I would recommend this course to another student. I thought the labs were fun and engaging and cool applications of the physiological concepts. Especially with labs counting as 0.5 credits, I really appreciated the shorter labs and every-other-week schedule. Lab reports were very time intensive, but with lab reports coming every 2 weeks, it was manageable.

As lab courses go, it's one of the better ones I've taken. I would recommend it only for BME majors for whom it is required. However, it isn't bad at all. You will learn some things and hopefully have some fun along the way.

I would recommend this course to students who need a biology lab and want to understand physiological principles behind commonly-used lab techniques. If you are a BME major, this course is a pretty low-stress way to learn a lot.
Yes because it is required of BME.
I would recommend this course if you are mainly a BME major, but it is doable for others as well. It is a cool course, and you learn alot of different things through fun experiments
Not if they don't need to take it.
Yes. This is a pretty chill and also fun lab class to take, and you get to learn a lot.

I would because of the relevant covering of physiological measurement techniques. The workload is not bad at all since most labs are spread out over 2 weeks. This course is definitely quality over quantity, something rarely seen in undergraduate teaching lab courses.
Yes, the labs were interesting.
